I know the topical response is to somehow level trade and there is some nebulous idea that someone somewhere has a plan to "bring back American jobs," but I don't buy any of that. Trump doesn't represent everyone and he's stated and acted as such many times.   I deeply suspect that this is a crisis to create a dependency on Trump to alleviate supply line resources to individual states and starve people into compliance with the mandates of Project 2025 and the mirror goals of big tech authoritarians. This and just about everything else this mf has done is treasonous.   It is treason to break our country. This should have required an invasion. There is no election that can justify this level of crookedness and damage done to the United States by this Weekend at Bernie's narcissist that shadowy organizations are propping up to implement an agenda nobody in this country would, if given an explanation out loud, ever support.  It's about to get real weird here.

Comment: > some nebulous idea that someone somewhere has a plan to "bring back American jobs"  There aren't even "concepts of a plan" on this one.    You can't "make enough money on tarriffs to eliminate income taxes" AND tariff foreign products enough to encourage domestic production AND make the bestest deals on tariffs simultaneously.  Those three are all mutually exclusive goals, yet Trump has been promising all 3.  Moving the needle on any of those things individually causes the others to get worse.

Comment: It’s a disconnect between perception and reality. The romanticized era of prosperity they are referring to (1950’s) was associated with the amount of manufacturing that was in the US. What is left out is the prevalence of unions and other worker’s rights. People think that bringing back manufacturing will return America to that prosperous time. But their refusal to also bring back the other half of that equation will more likely bring about more economic inequality.

Author: SeaBennys

Comment: What company would invest the money to do so when Trump is simultaneously promising to negotiate the bestest deals?  If you move production to the USA and he cuts a deal for cheaper imports from somewhere else, your investment has instantly gone up in smoke.    Similarly, if the US government can replace income taxes with tariffs (another thing they have been promising), that means that imported products still have to sell well enough to generate that tariff revenue.  That's literally the opposite of the protectionism you need to make a domestic industry viable when competing against cheaper production somewhere else.   It's all just a pile of self-contradictory nonsense.
Author: tomz17

I want them to state it out loud, though I know they never will. Author: Richard1583

Comment: True, but the ocean-crossing container ships that do the US/China routes are enormous.   The biggest heavy-lift semi-submersible ship is dwarfed by these 400 meter long monsters.  Empty they are still 55,000 tons.  Blue Marlin could theoretically carry the weight (DWT 70,000 tons), but there would be no way to support its length so it would break in two.   (and for the record, my above comment was meant to be a bit snarky.  I call big ships boats all the time, also to be snarky.)
Author: guttanzer

Comment: Was said by British Foreign Secretary Sir Edward Grey on the eve of the United Kingdom's entry into the First World War.   Technically, the full phrase is, "The lamps are going out all over Europe, we shall not see them lit again in our lifetime."
